_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:
In this manufacturing facility we import, store and process anhydrous ammonia which is considered an extremely hazardous chemical. The inherent properties of anhydrous ammonia make it necessary to observe strict safety precautions in its handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the threat to our personnel's health and to reduce the risk to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and Commonwealth regulations as they pertain to matters of environment, health and safety. Safety is dependant on the proper handling of ammonia, well maintained and properly operating equipment and thorough training of our personnel.
Our emergency response program is based upon the Compressed Gas Association, Inc./The Fertilizer Institute's "American National Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia," training programs developed by large ammonia manufacturers and good engineering practice. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local FD and state and local emergency planning/response committees.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.
This facility imports, stores and handles anhydrous ammonia for the production of ammonium sulfoxides and ammonium hydroxide. The anhydrous ammonia is shipped and received in IMO-V isotainers transported by ship and then hauled by truck to our facility where it is stored in four steel pressure gas tanks. Both the IMO-V containers and the storage tanks are equipped with safet relief valves and excess flow valves. It is transferred to the process via  1.5" schedule 80 steel pipe. The facility has the proper safety equipment to ensure safe unloading of the containers and to effect any required maintenance and/or repairs. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees and authorized management personnel.
The regulated substance handled at thi

s facility is anhydrous ammonia and the maximum amount that can be stored at any one time is 350,000 pounds.

3.THE WORST CASE SCENARIO(s) AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO(s), INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO. (INCLUDED THOUGH NOT REQUIRED)
Worst-Case Scenario: Failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the maximum amount allowed would release 108,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. Company policy limits the filling capacity of this tank to 90% at 85 degrees F. It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor. The distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst case scenario is 5.6 miles (9 km).
Alternative Scenario: Failure of 20 foot length of 2 inch hose used to unload the IMO-V containers to the storage tanks. Excess flow and check valves function to stop the flow. It is assumed that the entire contents of the hose (30 pounds) are released as vapor. The distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative scenario is less than 1000 feet. This release has the possibility of extending beyond the facility boundary.

4. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS.
This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule, OSHA's PSM/PHA Regulations and all applicable environment, safety and health regulations of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Good enginnering practice includes redundant excess flow valves on the liquid phase and excess flow valves on the gas draw off points. Third party inspection and certification of IMO-V containers and storage tanks is effected as required by regulations.

5. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.
There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia at this facility.

6. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.
This facility's emergency response program is based upon the "American National Standard Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia", large ammonia manufacturer training programs

and reference to both the North American Emergency Response Guidebook and EPA's Risk Management Program and Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration Facilities.

7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.
The anhydrous ammonia storage and transfer facilities are inspected weekly by operations personnel who receive annual refresher training and furthermore are tested/certified annually by an independent licenced examiner.
